trans-unit.source: Line of business application Phase 2 | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Line of business application Phase 2 | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Create and configure the two Active Directory replica domain controllers in Phase 2 of the line of business application in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Create and configure the two Active Directory replica domain controllers in Phase 2 of the line of business application in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Line of Business Application Workload Phase 2: Configure domain controllers
trans-unit.target: Line of Business Application Workload Phase 2: Configure domain controllers

trans-unit.source: In this phase of deploying a high-availability line of business application in Azure infrastructure services, you configure two replica domain controllers in the Azure Virtual Network so that client web requests for web resources can be authenticated locally within the Azure virtual network, rather than sending that authentication traffic across the connection to your on-premises network.
trans-unit.target: In this phase of deploying a high-availability line of business application in Azure infrastructure services, you configure two replica domain controllers in the Azure Virtual Network so that client web requests for web resources can be authenticated locally within the Azure virtual network, rather than sending that authentication traffic across the connection to your on-premises network.

trans-unit.source: You must complete this phase before moving on to <link><linkText>Phase 3</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: You must complete this phase before moving on to <link><linkText>Phase 3</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>Deploy a High-Availability Line of Business Application in Azure</linkText><title></title></link> for all of the phases.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>Deploy a High-Availability Line of Business Application in Azure</linkText><title></title></link> for all of the phases.

trans-unit.source: Create the domain controller virtual machines in Azure
trans-unit.target: Create the domain controller virtual machines in Azure

trans-unit.source: First, you need to fill out the Virtual machine name column of Table M and modify virtual machine sizes as needed in the Minimum size column.
trans-unit.target: First, you need to fill out the Virtual machine name column of Table M and modify virtual machine sizes as needed in the Minimum size column.

trans-unit.source: Item
trans-unit.target: Item

trans-unit.source: Virtual machine name
trans-unit.target: Virtual machine name

trans-unit.source: Gallery image
trans-unit.target: Gallery image

trans-unit.source: Minimum size
trans-unit.target: Minimum size

trans-unit.source: | __________ (first domain controller, example DC1) | Windows Server 2012 R2 Datacenter | Standard_D1
trans-unit.target: | __________ (first domain controller, example DC1) | Windows Server 2012 R2 Datacenter | Standard_D1

trans-unit.source: | __________ (second domain controller, example DC2) | Windows Server 2012 R2 Datacenter | Standard_D1
trans-unit.target: | __________ (second domain controller, example DC2) | Windows Server 2012 R2 Datacenter | Standard_D1

trans-unit.source: | __________ (primary database server, example SQL1) | Microsoft SQL Server 2014 Enterprise – Windows Server 2012 R2 | Standard_DS4
trans-unit.target: | __________ (primary database server, example SQL1) | Microsoft SQL Server 2014 Enterprise – Windows Server 2012 R2 | Standard_DS4

trans-unit.source: | __________ (secondary database server, example SQL2) | Microsoft SQL Server 2014 Enterprise – Windows Server 2012 R2 | Standard_DS4
trans-unit.target: | __________ (secondary database server, example SQL2) | Microsoft SQL Server 2014 Enterprise – Windows Server 2012 R2 | Standard_DS4

trans-unit.source: | __________ (majority node witness for the cluster, example MN1) | Windows Server 2012 R2 Datacenter | Standard_D1
trans-unit.target: | __________ (majority node witness for the cluster, example MN1) | Windows Server 2012 R2 Datacenter | Standard_D1

trans-unit.source: | __________ (first web server, example WEB1) | Windows Server 2012 R2 Datacenter | Standard_D3
trans-unit.target: | __________ (first web server, example WEB1) | Windows Server 2012 R2 Datacenter | Standard_D3

trans-unit.source: | __________ (second web server, example WEB2) | Windows Server 2012 R2 Datacenter | Standard_D3
trans-unit.target: | __________ (second web server, example WEB2) | Windows Server 2012 R2 Datacenter | Standard_D3

trans-unit.source: Table M – Virtual machines for the high-availability line of business application in Azure
trans-unit.target: Table M – Virtual machines for the high-availability line of business application in Azure

trans-unit.source: For the complete list of virtual machine sizes, see <link><linkText>Virtual Machine and Cloud Service Sizes for Azure</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For the complete list of virtual machine sizes, see <link><linkText>Virtual Machine and Cloud Service Sizes for Azure</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Use the following block of Azure PowerShell commands to create the virtual machines for the two domain controllers. Specify the values for the variables, removing the < and > characters. Note that this PowerShell command set uses values from the following:
trans-unit.target: Use the following block of Azure PowerShell commands to create the virtual machines for the two domain controllers. Specify the values for the variables, removing the < and > characters. Note that this PowerShell command set uses values from the following:

trans-unit.source: Table M, for your virtual machines
trans-unit.target: Table M, for your virtual machines

trans-unit.source: Table V, for your virtual network settings
trans-unit.target: Table V, for your virtual network settings

trans-unit.source: Table S, for your subnet
trans-unit.target: Table S, for your subnet

trans-unit.source: Table ST, for your storage accounts
trans-unit.target: Table ST, for your storage accounts

trans-unit.source: Table A, for your availability sets
trans-unit.target: Table A, for your availability sets

trans-unit.source: Recall that you defined Tables V, S, ST, and A in <link><linkText>Phase 1: Configure Azure</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Recall that you defined Tables V, S, ST, and A in <link><linkText>Phase 1: Configure Azure</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: When you have supplied all the proper values, run the resulting block at the Azure PowerShell prompt.
trans-unit.target: When you have supplied all the proper values, run the resulting block at the Azure PowerShell prompt.

trans-unit.source: Configure the first domain controller
trans-unit.target: Configure the first domain controller

trans-unit.source: Use the remote desktop client of your choice and create a remote desktop connection to the first domain controller virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Use the remote desktop client of your choice and create a remote desktop connection to the first domain controller virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Use its intranet DNS or computer name and the credentials of the local administrator account.
trans-unit.target: Use its intranet DNS or computer name and the credentials of the local administrator account.

trans-unit.source: Next, you need to add the extra data disk to the first domain controller.
trans-unit.target: Next, you need to add the extra data disk to the first domain controller.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>To initialize an empty disk
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>To initialize an empty disk

trans-unit.source: In the left pane of Server Manager, click File and Storage Services, and then click Disks.
trans-unit.target: In the left pane of Server Manager, click File and Storage Services, and then click Disks.

trans-unit.source: In the contents pane, in the Disks group, click disk 2 (with the Partition set to Unknown).
trans-unit.target: In the contents pane, in the Disks group, click disk 2 (with the Partition set to Unknown).

trans-unit.source: Click Tasks, and then click New Volume.
trans-unit.target: Click Tasks, and then click New Volume.

trans-unit.source: On the Before you begin page of the New Volume Wizard, click Next.
trans-unit.target: On the Before you begin page of the New Volume Wizard, click Next.

trans-unit.source: On the Select the server and disk page, click Disk 2, and then click Next.
trans-unit.target: On the Select the server and disk page, click Disk 2, and then click Next.

trans-unit.source: When prompted, click OK.
trans-unit.target: When prompted, click OK.

trans-unit.source: On the Specify the size of the volume page, click Next.
trans-unit.target: On the Specify the size of the volume page, click Next.

trans-unit.source: On the Assign to a drive letter or folder page, click Next.
trans-unit.target: On the Assign to a drive letter or folder page, click Next.

trans-unit.source: On the Select file system settings page, click Next.
trans-unit.target: On the Select file system settings page, click Next.

trans-unit.source: On the Confirm selections page, click Create.
trans-unit.target: On the Confirm selections page, click Create.

trans-unit.source: When complete, click Close.
trans-unit.target: When complete, click Close.

trans-unit.source: Next, test the first domain controller's connectivity to locations on your organization network.
trans-unit.target: Next, test the first domain controller's connectivity to locations on your organization network.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>To test connectivity
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>To test connectivity

trans-unit.source: From the desktop, open a Windows PowerShell prompt.
trans-unit.target: From the desktop, open a Windows PowerShell prompt.

trans-unit.source: Use the ping command to ping names and IP addresses of resources on your organization network.
trans-unit.target: Use the ping command to ping names and IP addresses of resources on your organization network.

trans-unit.source: This procedure ensures that DNS name resolution is working correctly (that the virtual machine is correctly configured with on-premises DNS servers) and that packets can be sent to and from the cross-premises virtual network.
trans-unit.target: This procedure ensures that DNS name resolution is working correctly (that the virtual machine is correctly configured with on-premises DNS servers) and that packets can be sent to and from the cross-premises virtual network.

trans-unit.source: If this basic test fails, contact your IT department to troubleshoot the DNS name resolution and packet delivery issues.
trans-unit.target: If this basic test fails, contact your IT department to troubleshoot the DNS name resolution and packet delivery issues.

trans-unit.source: Next, from the Windows PowerShell command prompt on the first domain controller, run the following commands:
trans-unit.target: Next, from the Windows PowerShell command prompt on the first domain controller, run the following commands:

trans-unit.source: You will be prompted to supply the credentials of a domain administrator account.
trans-unit.target: You will be prompted to supply the credentials of a domain administrator account.

trans-unit.source: The computer will restart.
trans-unit.target: The computer will restart.

trans-unit.source: Configure the second domain controller
trans-unit.target: Configure the second domain controller

trans-unit.source: Use the remote desktop client of your choice and create a remote desktop connection to the second domain controller virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Use the remote desktop client of your choice and create a remote desktop connection to the second domain controller virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Use its intranet DNS or computer name and the credentials of the local administrator account.
trans-unit.target: Use its intranet DNS or computer name and the credentials of the local administrator account.

trans-unit.source: Next, you need to add the extra data disk to the second domain controller.
trans-unit.target: Next, you need to add the extra data disk to the second domain controller.

trans-unit.source: See the <link><linkText>To initialize an empty disk procedure</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: See the <link><linkText>To initialize an empty disk procedure</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Next, from the Windows PowerShell prompt on the second domain controller, run the following commands:
trans-unit.target: Next, from the Windows PowerShell prompt on the second domain controller, run the following commands:

trans-unit.source: You will be prompted to supply the credentials of a domain administrator account.
trans-unit.target: You will be prompted to supply the credentials of a domain administrator account.

trans-unit.source: The computer will restart.
trans-unit.target: The computer will restart.

trans-unit.source: Next, you need to update the DNS servers for your virtual network so that Azure assigns virtual machines the IP addresses of the two new domain controllers to use as their DNS servers.
trans-unit.target: Next, you need to update the DNS servers for your virtual network so that Azure assigns virtual machines the IP addresses of the two new domain controllers to use as their DNS servers.

trans-unit.source: Note that this procedure uses values from Table V (for your virtual network settings) and Table M (for your virtual machines).
trans-unit.target: Note that this procedure uses values from Table V (for your virtual network settings) and Table M (for your virtual machines).

trans-unit.source: In the left pane of the Azure Preview portal, click Browse all > Virtual networks, and then click the name of your virtual network (Table V – Item 1 – Value column).
trans-unit.target: In the left pane of the Azure Preview portal, click Browse all > Virtual networks, and then click the name of your virtual network (Table V – Item 1 – Value column).

trans-unit.source: On the pane for your virtual network, click All settings.
trans-unit.target: On the pane for your virtual network, click All settings.

trans-unit.source: On the Settings pane, click DNS servers.
trans-unit.target: On the Settings pane, click DNS servers.

trans-unit.source: On the DNS servers pane, type the following:
trans-unit.target: On the DNS servers pane, type the following:

trans-unit.source: For Primary DNS server: Table V – Item 6 – Value column
trans-unit.target: For Primary DNS server: Table V – Item 6 – Value column

trans-unit.source: For Secondary DNS server: Table V – Item 7 – Value column
trans-unit.target: For Secondary DNS server: Table V – Item 7 – Value column

trans-unit.source: In the left pane of the Azure Preview portal, click Browse all > Virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: In the left pane of the Azure Preview portal, click Browse all > Virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: In the Virtual machines pane, click the name of your first domain controller (Table M – Item 1 - Virtual machine name column).
trans-unit.target: In the Virtual machines pane, click the name of your first domain controller (Table M – Item 1 - Virtual machine name column).

trans-unit.source: On the pane for the virtual machine, click Restart.
trans-unit.target: On the pane for the virtual machine, click Restart.

trans-unit.source: When the first domain controller is started, click the name of your second domain controller on the Virtual machines pane (Table M – Item 2 - Virtual machine name column).
trans-unit.target: When the first domain controller is started, click the name of your second domain controller on the Virtual machines pane (Table M – Item 2 - Virtual machine name column).

trans-unit.source: On the pane for the virtual machine, click Restart.
trans-unit.target: On the pane for the virtual machine, click Restart.

trans-unit.source: Wait until the second domain controller is started.
trans-unit.target: Wait until the second domain controller is started.

trans-unit.source: Note that we restart the two domain controllers so that they are not configured with the on-premises DNS servers as DNS servers.
trans-unit.target: Note that we restart the two domain controllers so that they are not configured with the on-premises DNS servers as DNS servers.

trans-unit.source: Because they are both DNS servers themselves, they were automatically configured with the on-premises DNS servers as DNS forwarders when they were promoted to domain controllers.
trans-unit.target: Because they are both DNS servers themselves, they were automatically configured with the on-premises DNS servers as DNS forwarders when they were promoted to domain controllers.

trans-unit.source: Next, we need to create an Active Directory replication site to ensure that servers in the Azure virtual network use the local domain controllers.
trans-unit.target: Next, we need to create an Active Directory replication site to ensure that servers in the Azure virtual network use the local domain controllers.

trans-unit.source: Log on to the primary domain controller with a domain administrator account and run the following commands from an administrator-level Windows PowerShell prompt:
trans-unit.target: Log on to the primary domain controller with a domain administrator account and run the following commands from an administrator-level Windows PowerShell prompt:

trans-unit.source: Next, add a user account to manage the SQL Server virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: Next, add a user account to manage the SQL Server virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: This diagram shows the configuration resulting from the successful completion of this phase, with placeholder computer names.
trans-unit.target: This diagram shows the configuration resulting from the successful completion of this phase, with placeholder computer names.

trans-unit.source: Next step
trans-unit.target: Next step

trans-unit.target: To continue with the configuration of this workload, go to <link><linkText>Phase 3: Configure SQL Server infrastructure</linkText><title></title></link>.
